section .bss

section .text

%macro error 2

    mov rax,4
    mov rbx,1

    mov rdx,%2

% exit 0

    mov rax,1
    mov rbx,0

    .repeat:

%endmacro

    xor rcx,rcx                               ;This will work as a counter
    xor rax,rax                               ;This will store the result

    sub bl,48                                 ;Changes byte value to the integer number

%endmacro

_start:
    xor r9,r9                                 ;r9 will store bytes

answers.body_markdown:
Flutter style behaves similarly to Vue scoped styled / React "styled-component" or React native in general:

There's no "global style" in these scenarios. Instead, you use composition to obtain the desired result.

In a sense, you have one StatelessWidget for each "CSS class", instead of one big StatelessWidget with many parameters.

For example, say we want to split a "red background + border radius" into reusable styles, then we'd typically have two widgets:

- RedBackground
- MyBorder


where you would then be able to use them independently:

```dart
RedBackground(
  child: Text('hello world'),
)
```

or together:

```dart
RedBackground(
  child: MyBorder(
    child: Text('hello world'),
  ),
)
```

answers.body_markdown:
You have a bug in line 11:

    if [[ ! -e $@ ]]; then

You do need to check for a given file here using `$var` like that:

    if [[ ! -e "$var" ]]; then

And you exit prematurely in line 23 - you will always print only a
single file. And remember to always quote your variable because
otherwise your script would not run correctly on files that have a whitespaces in the name, for example:

    $ echo a line > 'a b'
    $ cat 'a b'
    a line
    $ ./concat.sh 'a b'
    cat: a: No such file or directory
    cat: b: No such file or directory
    -----.

You said:

> if a file does not exist, the error must be printed to stderr and
> nothing should be printed to stdout.

You aren't printing anything to stderr at the moment, if you want to
you should do:

    echo ... >&2

And you should use `printf` instead of `echo` as it's more portable
even though you're using `Bash`.

All in all, your script could look like this:

    #!/bin/bash
    
    if [ $# -eq 0 ]; then
        printf "Usage: concat FILE ... \nDescription: Concatenates FILE(s) to standard output separating them with divider -----.\n" >&2
        exit 1
    fi
    
    for var in "$@"
    do
        if [[ ! -e "$var" ]]; then
                printf "One or more files does not exist\n" >&2
                exit 1
        fi
    done
        
    for var in "$@"
    do
        if [ -f "$var" ]; then
                cat "$var"
                printf -- "-----\n"
        fi
    done
    
    exit 0

You need to create a Mongoose model using the UserSchema and name it 'User'. You can then create a Match model using the MatchSchema. Assuming the UserSchema and MatchSchema are in the same file, you can add the following:

````
const User = mongoose.model('User', UserSchema)
const Match = mongoose.model('Match', MatchSchema)

````
Then when you want to populate the Match model with User data:
````
let data = Match.find({})
             .populate('player_one.player_details')
             .populate('player_two.player_details')
````

answers.title: what is the meaning of &address

answers.body_markdown:
> What is the meaning of `&address`?

It is the same as the meaning of `&m`, except for a different variable. `&` is the addressof operator, and `&address` is the memory address where the object named by the identifier `address` is stored. In the example, `&a` is where `a` is stored. Function arguments are local variables.

Furthermore, since `a` is a pointer to `int`, the type of pointer to `a` is pointer to pointer to `int` i.e. `int**`.

<sub>Although the example doesn't involve reference variables, note that when the operand of addressof operator is a reference, the result will be the address of the referred object. Reference variables are not objects and don't necessarily have a memory address at all.</sub>
answers.title: what is the meaning of &address

answers.body_markdown:
I would recommend using [.limit()][1] and [.skip()][2] and adding paging to your API endpoint.

Limit limits the number of documents returned while skip skips a given number of documents. Usually this is used with `.sort()` to return documents in a given order such as their creation datetime.

```
Model.find(...).sort(...).limit(req.query.limit).skip(req.query.skip).exec(function(error, docs) {});
```

Example for paging:

Your app sends a request such as `GET /api/users?limit=20&skip=0` to get first 20.

Then it sends a request such as `GET /api/users?limit=20&skip=20` to get the next 20.

  [1]: https://mongoosejs.com/docs/api.html#query_Query-limit
  [2]: https://mongoosejs.com/docs/api.html#query_Query-skip

answers.body_markdown:
The data that can be returned by the .info.get method is stored in a dictionary that is not universally used by the various devices and programs that write exif data to image files. If it's returning "None," it's because nothing had been put there in the first place, or since there's no standard for how data is stored in it, in a key-value pair you're not expecting. 

The larger issue here is that DPI is not a fixed property of an image--it's a term that's relative to the expected size of the image as printed on paper or screen. If, for instance, you display a jpg produced by a digital camera or cell-phone directly on a monitor screen, it will typically be displayed at 72dpi and you'll be able to see only a small portion of the image. At that resolution, the full-sized image would be huge--more than a meter wide and proportionally height. But if printed at, say, 300dpi, the whole image might fit nicely on an 8.5x11/A4 sheet of paper. 

Since the camera or program doesn't necessary know how the image will be displayed or printed, it doesn't necessarily include resolution information in the EXIF data. More accessible is the data on the absolute size of the image in pixels: x wide and y high. Given those dimensions, the "dpi" of the image entirely depends on the physical size (in imperial inches: dots-per-inch) of the image output to paper or screen.

answers.body_markdown: Classes are a C++ feature and don't exist in C, so the C compiler rightly gives you an error about them, since you're trying to use "pure C". Since the schema is known ahead of time, you can make a list for each column and build a dictionary of _column name and column values_ pairs.

```ipython
%%timeit -r 10
import pyarrow as pa
import random
import string 
import time

large_dict = dict()

for i in range(int(1e6)):
    large_dict[i] = (random.randint(0, 5), random.choice(string.ascii_letters))


schema = pa.schema({
        "key"  : pa.uint32(),
        "col1" : pa.uint8(),
        "col2" : pa.string()
  })

keys = []
val1 = []
val2 = []
for k, (v1, v2) in large_dict.items():
  keys.append(k)
  val1.append(v1)
  val2.append(v2)

table = pa.Table.from_pydict(
    dict(
        zip(schema.names, (keys, val1, val2))
    ),
    schema=schema
)
```

> 2.92 s ± 236 ms per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 10 runs, 1 loop each)

items.body_markdown:
I have a large dictionary that I want to iterate through to build a pyarrow table. The values of the dictionary are tuples of varying types and need to be unpacked and stored in separate columns in the final pyarrow table. I do know the schema ahead of time. The keys also need to be stored as a column. I have a method below to construct the table row by row - is there another method that is faster? For context, I want to parse a large dictionary into a pyarrow table to write out to a parquet file. RAM usage is less of a concern than CPU time. I'd prefer not to drop down to the arrow C++ API.

```
import pyarrow as pa
import random
import string 
import time

large_dict = dict()

for i in range(int(1e6)):
    large_dict[i] = (random.randint(0, 5), random.choice(string.ascii_letters))
    

schema = pa.schema({
        "key"  : pa.uint32(),
        "col1" : pa.uint8(),
        "col2" : pa.string()
   })

start = time.time()

tables = []
for key, item in large_dict.items():
    val1, val2 = item
    tables.append(
            pa.Table.from_pydict({
                    "key"  : [key],
                    "col1" : [val1],
                    "col2" : [val2]
                }, schema = schema)
            
            )

table = pa.concat_tables(tables)
end = time.time()
print(end - start) # 22.6 seconds on my machine

```
items.title: Fastest way to construct pyarrow table row by row

answers.body_markdown:
Not clear whether the input should be the `my_list`.  If the intention is to loop over the `list` (instead of `unlist`ing), then use `map`, apply the `str_extract_all` (it can be directly applied on the `vector`), `enframe` into a two column tibble, `unnest` the 'value' column, convert it to `integer` (as `str_extract_all` returns a `list` of strings, `deframe` the data.frame to a named `vector`, and convert it to `list`

    library(tidyverse)
    out <- map_df(my_list, ~ set_names(str_extract_all(.x, "\\d+"), .x)  %>% 
                enframe %>%        
                unnest(value)  %>%
                mutate(value = as.integer(value))) %>%
           deframe %>% 
           as.list
    all.equal(out, goal_list)
    #[1] TRUE

---

Or in another way, use `str_count` to get the number of digits in the name, `rep`licate the `names` of the data.frame based on that, extract the digits from the `names` with `str_extract_all`, set its names with the replicated names, and convert the `vector` to a `list` with `as.list`

    as.list(setNames(as.integer(unlist(str_extract_all(names(df), "\\d+"))), 
                  rep(names(df), str_count(names(df), "\\d+"))))



---

Or using only `base R`

    l1 <- regmatches(names(df), gregexpr("\\d+", names(df)))
    as.list(with(transform(stack(setNames(l1, names(df))), 
          values = as.integer(values)), setNames(values, ind)))

NOTE: `assign` is not needed here as it is to assign values to an identifier object

answers.body_markdown:
The statement `return (x = x + 2, x + 1);` is equivalent to:
```c
x = x + 2; // x == 7
return x + 1; // returns 8
```
answers.title: Why is the return value of the fun function 8 instead of 7?
Why is the return value of the fun function 8 instead of 7?

answers.body_markdown:
When writing ```return (x=x+2,x+1)```, the first expression is evaluated first so ```x=x+2``` is evaluated, causing x to equal 7 as a side effect. Then the second expression is evaluated and returned, hence the function returns x+1 hence returns 8.

If you had written ```return (x+2,x+1);```, the result would have been 6 because the first expression ```x+2``` doesn't have any side effect.
answers.title: Why is the return value of the fun function 8 instead of 7?

answers.body_markdown:
Both parts in the `return` are evaluated respectively and the result of the last instruction is returned:

At first we have:
```
x = x + 2 // 7
```
Now `x` is updated to `7` before the second evaluation which gives:
```
x + 1 // 7 + 1 = 8
```
and finally return ` 8`.

For better understanding consider the case of intermediate variable as follows:
```
return (y = x + 2, y + 1);
```
answers.title: Why is the return value of the fun function 8 instead of 7?
Why is the return value of the fun function 8 instead of 7?

answers.body_markdown:
That's a matter of operator precedence.

`x=x+2,x+1` is evaluated as `(x=x+2), (x+1)` and not as `x=(x+2,x+1)`
answers.title: Why is the return value of the fun function 8 instead of 7?

answers.body_markdown:
The comma operator introduces a sequence point in your code. The statements are evaluated in this order:

1. `x = x + 2`, at which point the local `x` in `fun` is 7.

2. `x + 1`, which evaluates to 8, and is returned.

To clarify, here's a parenthesized version showing operator precedence:

    return (x=x+2),x+1;

The left-hand expression is evaluated and its value is thrown away. The right-hand expression's value is what is returned.
answers.title: Why is the return value of the fun function 8 instead of 7?

          . . .

because this formula could use an index if available.

answers.body_markdown:
From the [accept(2) manpage][1]:

>        The accept() system call is used with connection-based socket types
       (SOCK_STREAM, SOCK_SEQPACKET).  It extracts the first connection
       request on the queue of pending connections for the listening socket,
       sockfd, creates a new connected socket, and returns a new file
       descriptor referring to that socket.  The newly created socket is not
       in the listening state.  The original socket sockfd is unaffected by
       this call.

So other connections are building up in a queue on the original socket, waiting for your application to respond to them by calling `accept()` on it again. (Bugs aside, there's no such thing as other connections that want to be bound to the state of the newly accepted socket since unlike a LISTENING socket, it is bound to the specific source address and port of the client that was accepted off the queue.)

Consequently, you should design your application to get back to calling accept on the original LISTEN socket in a reasonable amount of time. Some people use threading, some people fork to have another process for handling each new socket, some people prevent large tasks either on any one socket in their protocol or at any iteration in a main loop that examines each ongoing task at each interval and does a set amount of work.

If you do nothing but accept new sockets as old ones are done then a number of clients will sit patiently waiting if they are trivial and will probably give up on their connections if they are less trivial implementations from existing protocols.

  [1]: http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man2/accept.2.html

items.body_markdown:
When targeting the .Net Framework, my company mandates that all assemblies must be strongly named and Authenticode signed. The idea being that the main executable is guaranteed to come from our company, and all of the strongly named assemblies that come with it are guaranteed to be the correct, untampered original from our build server i.e. we are using strong naming as a security feature. This is intended to prevent an employee without the private signing key disassembling a .dll, inserting some rogue code and rebuilding it locally, before overwriting the original assembly.

Previously in .Net, strong naming was "viral"; any assembly that was strong named could only reference strong named assemblies, and trying to replace the original assembly with a different version would cause a runtime exception.

With .Net Core that appears to have changed. [See here][1]. Not only are strongly named assemblies not required to reference strong named assemblies, even if you do reference a strong named assembly at compile time, someone can replace the binary with a weak named assembly without experiencing a runtime exception (I've tested this). [This][2] Microsoft page seems to contain contradictory text.

> One important aspect of strong naming is that it's viral: a strong named assembly can only reference other strong named assemblies.
> 
>  .NET Core, Xamarin, UWP, and most other .NET implementations don't have strict assembly loading and removes the main downside of strong naming.

**Is there any way to mandate that all .Net Core assemblies in a project are strongly name and cannot be replaced with different assemblies post compilation?**

  [1]: https://github.com/dotnet/roslyn/issues/7277
  [2]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/library-guidance/strong-naming
items.title: Force all assemblies to be strong named in CoreCLR

answers.body_markdown:
SQL parameters are used only for values, hence cannot be used for column or table names. Behind the scene, when preparing a statement, the RDBMS needs to fully understand the query that will later on be executed. Changing a column or table name does change the meaning of a query, so this is not supported.

Bottom line, you mentionned that the column and table names do not come from user input, so that removes the risk of SQL injection anyway. If they were coming from outside the program, then a solution would be to programmatically verify them (eg against predefined list of values).

answers.title: What are the requirements for a Powerpoint VSTO add-in manifest?

items.body_markdown:
## Background / Goal

I have written a VSTO-based add-in for Microsoft Powerpoint. Due to the requirements of the add-in and the current JavaScript API surface for PowerPoint add-ins, I was unable to use the newer web-based format for add-ins as it did not have the capabilities I needed.

My goal is to be able to submit the VSTO add-in to AppSource so that it can make its way to the Office add-in store.

## Problem / Question

Now that my add-in is ready, I need to create a manifest file for it in order to publish it for others to consume.

However, all of the guidance I can find online points to a manifest format that appears to be geared toward the newer, web-based approaches rather than the older VSTO/COM-based approach.

So my question is:

* For a PowerPoint VSTO add-in that creates a Task Panel and a Ribbon entry (both in the format of controls within my solution), what are the requirements for an add-in manifest XML file?
* Are there any locations where one can see a template for VSTO add-ins rather than the newer web-based format?

## What I have Tried so Far

* I've looked in the documents for applicable examples but they all appear to refer to web-based add-in schema fields. 
* I've published the VSTO project to a folder to attempt to use the `.manifest` or `.vsto` files during app registration, but I receive the error `Your manifest does not reference any supported Office Add-in namespace. The most recent version is http://schemas.microsoft.com/office/appforoffice/1.1.`
items.title: What are the requirements for a Powerpoint VSTO add-in manifest?

I was generating my session_id() with $impressionId="Imp".substr(microtime(),11,11).substr(microtime(),1,7)
resulting in a string in the format Imp1568485583.309708
As soon as I removed the decimal point it worked!

I spent 3 days breaking my head over this, and as soon as I posted here I get the answer.

If you visit the offical docker hub of PHP, nodejs and golang you will be surprised.

- Nodejs approximately **80MB** (Alpine)

Leave the rest of that you mentioned in the question, for instance, subtract **5MB** in each due to OS alpine size still it above **800MB** which is ultimately become big and big by adding the rest.

Alternatively, you can multi-stage image but again you will have to manage and put conditional statements in your Dockerfile to deal with a command like `npm install` in nodejs and do `composer install` in PHP and bla bla.

You might build an image like this but again it will have to manage like a mess.
```
ARG BASE_IMAGE="go"
FROM golang:alpine as go

FROM node:alpine as node

FROM php:7.0-apache as php

FROM nginx:alpine as nginx

FROM ${BASE_IMAGE}
ENV BASE_IMAGE=$BASE_IMAGE
```




> Limiting each container to one process is a good [rule of thumb][1]

If the rule of thumb for the container to have one process per container then I think it should have an environment for that process only.

answers.body_markdown:
Reading PWM / PPM requires microsecond precision which might not be easily possible on Raspberry Pi.

The easiest way to capture PPM reliably would be to get a cheap microcontroller with serial or I2C interface and hook it to your Raspberry Pi.

Firstly, you can try understanding how Pulse Position Modulation (PPM) works. PPM is somewhat like PWM, except that it's the time between pulses that carries the data, and not the duration of the pulse itself. [Reference][4]

[![PPM Frame][1]][1]

You can use hardware timed sampling of **pigpio** to calculate the time periods between RISING edges of your PPM frame.

[![enter image description here][2]][2]

Alternatively, you can use [hardware interrupt][3] on an Arduino to calculate the time periods between RISING edges of your PPM frame and send the output to your RaspberryPi over serial or I2C.

Here is a brilliant [article][4] which could be a good starting point. 


  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/hy1FO.jpg
  [2]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/oDXeS.jpg
  [3]: https://www.arduino.cc/reference/en/language/functions/external-interrupts/attachinterrupt/
  [4]: https://hackaday.io/project/2465-manucon-a-glove-based-controller/log/8254-ppm-output

answers.body_markdown: You are in the direction. You can replace `O(log(log n))` with `c log(log n)` and be sure that there exists a constant `c` that `2 ^ O(log(log n)) < 2 ^ (c log(log n))`. Hence, we will have `S = 2^ (c log(log n)) =  (2^(log(log n)))^c = log(n)^c`. However, you **can't** say `S = O(log n)`. As `c` could be any constant number, you can say `S = O(n^epsilon)` that `epsilon` could be a small constant near to zero.
answers.title: Does 2 ^ O(log log n) = O(log n)?

answers.body_markdown:
No. Assuming a base-2 log, then

2<sup>log log N</sup> = log N,

but 2<sup>10 log log N</sup> is also in 2<sup>O(log log N)</sup>, and 

2<sup>10 log log N</sup> = (2<sup>log log N</sup>)<sup>10</sup> = (log N)<sup>10</sup>

...and that is obviously not in O(log N)

answers.body_markdown:
Invalidating causes `WM_PAINT` to be sent, and these are processed somehow "asynchronously", as `WM_PAINT` (`OnDraw()`)is a low-priority message (processed just before the message-queue is emptied). This can also cause "flickering". As mouse-move is a message sent many times as you move the mouse, you should rather not invalidate the window and better not perform lengthy/CPU-costly operations in there. Instead, I would consider a combination of painting and drawing. Details in the links below (related questions I have answered in the past):

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/56024993/some-controls-are-not-drawing-seemingly-at-random/56050188#56050188

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/55287210/mfc-window-graphic-is-gone-after-minimizing-maximizing/55290554#55290554

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/43825479/paint-invalid-areas-of-a-window-using-win32-api-and-gdi/43876162#43876162

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/39316141/win32api-why-should-i-getdc-and-releasedc-again-and-again/39317316#39317316

As for the crashes, they are no-doubt a result of implementation errors - the "asynchronous" nature of `WM_PAINT` message-processing may have sth to do here, eg some variables may have been changed (in `OnMouseMove()`), and when they are finally accessed in `OnDraw()` some data may be inconsistent.

answers.body_markdown:
1. When you navigate away from the page the [WebElements][1] get invalidated as [DOM][2] changes therefore I would recommend going for [List Comprehension][3] and convert the list of WebElements into the list of links text. 
 2. Once done you should be able to use [normalize-text()][4] function just in case the text belongs to child element or has starting/trailing spaces
 3. And last but not the least consider using [Explicit Wait][5] just in case the link is populated via [AJAX][6] call. 

Example code:

    driver.get("http://yandex.ru")
    links = [link.text for link in driver.find_elements_by_css_selector("a")]
    for link in links:
        WebDriverWait(driver, 10) \
            .until(expected_conditions
            .presence_of_element_located(
            (By.XPATH, "//a[normalize-space()='" + link + "']"))).click()
        # do what you need here
        print(driver.title)
        driver.back()
    driver.quit()


  [1]: https://selenium-python.readthedocs.io/api.html#module-selenium.webdriver.remote.webelement
  [2]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Document_Object_Model
  [3]: https://www.pythonforbeginners.com/basics/list-comprehensions-in-python
  [4]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/XPath/Functions/normalize-space
  [5]: https://experitest.com/selenium-testing/ajax_technology_selenium/
  [6]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ajax_(programming)

Remove duplicates from labelList

Transform df into a source-target pair

    for i in range(len(cat_cols)-1):

add index for source-target pair
